G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as both Plaintiff and Defendant reside in Massachusetts and this action concerns the custody and parenting of minor children habitually residing in the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as both Plaintiff and Defendant reside in Massachusetts and this action concerns the custody and parenting of minor children habitually residing in the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 8.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 8, as both parties reside in Bristol County.

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The current parenting plan no longer serves the best interests of the minor children, as it jeopardizes their safety, stability, and routine, contrary to the principles established in *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion applies the best-interests-of-the-child standard to an initial custody determination between two legal parents; it does not address modification of an existing parenting plan on the ground that a current plan no longer serves the children’s best interests or jeopardizes safety, stability, or routine. Hunter v. Rose discusses factors like stability, parental alienation, and ability to support the child’s relationship with the other parent, but it is not authority for the specific proposition that a *current* parenting plan must be changed because it now endangers those interests. Using it for that proposition stretches the holding beyond its context.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent…. The judge has discretion when awarding custody of a child to which we give ‘substantial deference.’”

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: A complaint for modification may be granted upon a showing of a "material and substantial change in circumstances" that affects the best interests of the children.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion in Schechter v. Schechter concerns an initial divorce judgment, including custody, visitation, a 209A order, removal, a prenuptial agreement, and attorney’s fees. It does not address the standard for granting a complaint for modification, nor does it mention or apply a "material and substantial change in circumstances" test. Therefore it cannot be authority for the proposition about the standard for modification of custody orders.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt:
In this case, the judge made findings that the father was domineering in his relations with the mother and child.... The findings are amply supported by the evidence and demonstrate that the decision to suspend the father’s visitation rights with the child was based on the exercise of a sound discretion.

[The opinion elsewhere discusses removal and best interests but does not address modification standards or "material and substantial change in circumstances."]

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The best interests of the child are paramount in all custody decisions.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal and custody-related determinations, “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern.” The court then applies that standard throughout its discussion of both custody and removal, confirming that best interests is the controlling, paramount consideration in these custody decisions.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “As most recently reformulated by the Supreme Court of New Jersey in Cooper v. Cooper, 99 N.J. 42 (1984), the ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’ Id. at 53. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Parental unavailability or inability to meet scheduled parenting commitments may constitute a material change in circumstances.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the general standard that child custody determinations must be based on the welfare and best interests of the child, and criticizes the trial judge for not applying those criteria. It does not discuss parental unavailability, inability to meet scheduled parenting commitments, or material changes in circumstances as a basis for modification. Thus, it does not establish or affirm the specific proposition claimed.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: A parent leaving children unsupervised or with third parties not approved by the custodial parent raises legitimate concerns regarding the children’s welfare.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss a parent leaving children unsupervised or with unapproved third parties, nor does it frame such conduct as a specific basis for concern about the child’s welfare. The custody analysis focuses on work schedules, day care usage, medical attentiveness, and continuity/stability, not supervision problems or unauthorized caregivers. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the stated proposition.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: [No passage in this opinion addresses a parent leaving the child unsupervised or with third parties not approved by the custodial parent, or treats such conduct as a distinct welfare concern. The discussion instead centers on best interests, primary caregiver status, work hours, day care arrangements, and parental attentiveness to medical and daily needs.]

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: Courts have found that modifications should account for changes in a parent’s work schedule where the changes interfere with the original parenting arrangement.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal/relocation request and a related child support modification, not a modification driven by a change in a parent’s work schedule. The court’s analysis focuses on the Yannas ‘real advantage’ and best interests framework and on whether the mother’s remarriage and desire to move justify relocation, and separately on the financial effect of her remarriage on child support. There is no discussion of altered work hours or schedules interfering with an existing parenting plan as a basis for modification.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “On July 10, 2012, the mother filed a complaint for modification alleging, as a change in circumstances, that she was to be married on August 3, 2012, to a resident of Danville, California. For this reason, the complaint sought removal of the minor children to California… Sometime thereafter, the father filed his own complaint for modification, wherein he sought to (1) reduce his child support obligation to the mother due to the financial support she receives from her new husband; and (2) establish a defined holiday and vacation schedule for the parties’ children.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The Plaintiff’s request is consistent with the Massachusetts principle that stability in the parenting plan and home environment is critical to the welfare of the children.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the obligation of Massachusetts courts to make explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects on children when determining custody. While it recognizes the harm caused when the home is a place of danger rather than security, it does not articulate or apply a general Massachusetts principle that stability in the parenting plan or continuity of a particular custodial arrangement is itself critical to children’s welfare. The remand is about properly weighing domestic violence, not about preserving an existing parenting plan for reasons of stability, so the case does not meaningfully support the cited proposition.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: "Particularly for children the sense that the place which is supposed to be the place of security is the place of greatest danger is the ultimate denial that this is a world of justice and restraint, where people have rights and are entitled to respect.... Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking."

*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.proposition: The facts here also align with rulings in *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (1987), and *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981), which emphasize the importance of parental availability during parenting time.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion cites Rolde v. Rolde for the general best-interests-of-the-child standard but does not itself emphasize or analyze the specific factor of parental availability during parenting time. Its custody analysis focuses on home state, continuity of residence, sibling relationships, community ties, and each parent’s fitness and travel ability, not on which parent would be physically available during parenting time. Thus, while Bak applies the best-interests framework, it does not independently stand for the narrower proposition that parental availability during parenting time is a key emphasized factor.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.relevant_excerpt: “Finally, Anthony maintains that the grant of custody of Rosemary and Tony to Sonja was wrong. A Probate Court judge must settle custody in a manner that advances the best interests of the children. Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 402 (1981), and cases cited. The decision of which parent will promote a child’s best interests ‘is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.’”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: The facts here also align with rulings in *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (1987), and *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981), which emphasize the importance of parental availability during parenting time.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on custody, joint vs. sole custody, and the scope of visitation, but it does not treat parental physical availability during parenting time as a distinct, emphasized factor. The reasoning is framed almost entirely in terms of the best interests of the children, parental conflict, and the impracticality of joint custody, not on how available a parent is during his or her visitation or parenting periods. Thus, citing Rolde as authority that emphasizes the importance of parental availability during parenting time somewhat overstates and mischaracterizes its holding.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “The ‘best interests’ principle requires that the narrow focus be on the interests of the child. … Joint custody is synonymous with joint decision making and a common desire to promote the children’s best interests. … Children are entitled to the love, companionship and concern of both parents, and they usually are better off if the parents can agree to share in the responsibility of their rearing as well as in physical custody.”
